answers.author: Alexandra Iannolo
answers.text:
Hello,
I found some resources that may help answer your question. 
Many areas have website pages dedicated to spreading CIP information. You may want to contact them directly for more information on what protocol is or is not required for the projects they list.
Lane County, Oregon has a page listing public hearings, important documents and contact information for their CIP work.
http://www.co.lane.or.us/Departments/PW/TransPlanning/Pages/1115cip.aspx
Libertyville, Illinois offers e-mail alerts for residents about construction updates in addition to online postings.
http://www.libertyville.com/index.aspx?nid=404 
Framingham, Massachusetts offers a similar service of public notice which includes emails and detailed maps.
http://www.buildingframingham.com/
I also found an example of a CIP resolution from Owasso, Oklahoma. In the “whereas” section it says approval hinges on, “properly notifying the public.” It also mandates a hearing but leaves the other language open ended.
http://www.cityofowasso.com/3rd_penny_projects/ThirdPenny%207.pdf
Kirkland, Wash. created an online survey to get feedback about how effective their CIP notifications were.  Their survey mentions signs. http://www.kirklandwa.gov/depart/Public_Works/Capital_Improvements/PW_CIP_feedback.htm
I hope these offer some assistance.
Does anyone have other examples of CIP transparency efforts even when it is not required?  
Ali Iannolo
Knowledge Network Intern
aiannolo@ICMA.org

Thank you for your assistance. I was able to locate a few cities in Texas that have CIP sign requirements. I am mainly interested in learning which cities have sign requirements for capital improvement projects and why such requirements were adopted.

author: Sarah Saunders
text:
The City of Tamarac, Florida is interested in learning if any municipalities currently REQUIRE announcing or project signs to be placed at the location of Capital Improvement Projects to inform the public about the project (in instances where there is no other requirement/obligation, i.e. grant funded). Our City currently does not have a requirement to do so, however as a way to promote transparency we have posted signs at some locations. These signs state what type of project is occurring and provide contact information, the City logo, and Commissioners' names. We are interested in learning if other municipalities require this, and your responses would be greatly appreciated. Additionally, if it is possible, please provide a copy of the code/ordinance that requires such signage. 
We look forward to your responses!
Thank you!
title: Does your city require CIP Project Signs be posted?
